revision.text:
{{short description|2003 single by Justin Timberlake}} {{about|the Justin Timberlake song|the Black Eyed Peas song|Rock That Body|the VIXX song|Rock Ur Body (VIXX song)}} {{good article}} {{Infobox song | name = Rock Your Body | cover = Rock Your Body cover.png | alt = | border = yes | type = single | artist = [[Justin Timberlake]] | album = [[Justified (album)|Justified]] | released = {{start date|2003|04|08}} | format = [[Maxi single]] | recorded = 2002; Master Sound Recording Studios, Windmark Recording ([[Virginia Beach, Virginia|Virginia Beach]]) | studio = | venue = | genre = {{Flat list| *[[Disco]] *[[Contemporary R&B|R&B]]}} | length = {{duration|m=4|s=27}} | label = [[Jive Records|Jive]] | writer = {{Flat list| *Justin Timberlake *[[Chad Hugo]] *[[Pharrell Williams]]}} | producer = [[The Neptunes]] | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = | misc = {{Extra chronology | artist = [[Justin Timberlake]] | type = singles | prev_title = [[Work It (Nelly song)|Work It]] | prev_year = 2003 | title = Rock Your Body | year = 2003 | next_title = [[Señorita (Justin Timberlake song)|Señorita]] | next_year = 2003 }} {{External music video|{{YouTube|TSVHoHyErBQ|"Rock Your Body"}}}} }}
"'''Rock Your Body'''" is a song by American singer-songwriter [[Justin Timberlake]] for his debut studio album, ''[[Justified (album)|Justified]]'' (2002). Timberlake co-wrote the song with its producers, [[The Neptunes]] (consisting of [[Chad Hugo]] and [[Pharrell Williams]]). [[Jive Records]] released the track on April 8, 2003 as the third single from ''Justified''. Originally intended to be featured on [[Michael Jackson]]'s tenth studio album ''[[Invincible (Michael Jackson album)|Invincible]]'' (2001), Jackson rejected the song along with several other tracks, which were instead given to Timberlake for his debut album. It is an uptempo, [[disco]] [[Groove (music)|groove]], [[Soul music|soul]] infused song containing influences from Jackson and [[Stevie Wonder]].
The song received generally positive reviews, with [[Music journalism|music critics]] noting it as a stand-out track, while complimenting its musical elements. "Rock Your Body" topped the [[ARIA Charts|Australian Singles Chart]]. It peaked at number two on the [[UK Singles Chart]] and became the third single from ''Justified'' to do so, following "[[Like I Love You]]" and "[[Cry Me a River (Justin Timberlake song)|Cry Me a River]]". It also charted at number five on the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]. It was certified gold by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA) and by the [[British Phonographic Industry]] (BPI) for sales of 500,000 and 400,000 copies, respectively.
The accompanying music video for "Rock Your Body", which was directed by [[Francis Lawrence]], features Timberlake with several back-up dancers performing choreography within a multi-color lighted cube. Timberlake performed the song live several times, including the highly controversial performance at the [[Super Bowl XXXVIII halftime show controversy|Super Bowl XXXVIII halftime show]] with [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] singer [[Janet Jackson]], referred to as a "[[wardrobe malfunction]]".
==Writing and recording== "Rock Your Body" was written by Timberlake, and its producers Hugo and Williams.<ref name="Notes">{{cite AV media notes|others=Justin Timberlake|title=[[Justified (album)|Justified]]|year=2002|type= inlay cover|publisher= [[Jive Records]]}}</ref> It was recorded at Master Sound Recording Studios and Windmark Recording, both located in [[Virginia Beach]] with Andrew Coleman serving as a [[recording engineer]].<ref name="Notes"/> It was [[Mixing (music production)|mixed]] by Serban Ghenea at Windmark Recording, with Daniel Botancourt and Tim Roberts aiding as additional engineers.<ref name="Notes"/> John Hanes provided additional Pro Tools engineering. All the [[Instrumentation (music)|instrumentation]] was delivered by Hugo and Williams, with vocal arrangements handled by the latter and Timberlake.<ref name="Notes"/> Vanessa Marquez provided additional vocals, which were recorded by Eddie Delena at the [[Record Plant]] located in [[Los Angeles]].<ref name="Notes"/> "Rock Your Body" was initially given to Michael Jackson for his tenth and final studio album ''[[Invincible (Michael Jackson album)|Invincible]]'' (2001), along with several other songs by The Neptunes.<ref name="Material">{{cite web|title=20 Hit Songs Meant For Other Singers|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=February 28, 2013|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/pop-shop/1550426/20-hit-songs-meant-for-other-singers|accessdate=April 15, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Material1">{{cite news|first=Madeline|last=Boardman|title=Justin Timberlake's 'Rock Your Body' Meant For Michael Jackson, And Other Hits That Were Passed On|publisher=[[AOL]]|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=April 3, 2013|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/03/04/justin-timberlakes-rock-your-body-meant-for-michael-jackson_n_2805413.html|accessdate=April 15, 2013}}</ref> The singer did not want any of the tracks, and so all the material was passed onto Timberlake for his debut album, ''Justified''.<ref name="Material"/><ref name="Material1"/>
==Composition and reception== {{Listen | pos = right | filename = Rock Your Body.ogg | title = "Rock Your Body" | description = "Rock Your Body" is an [[Tempo|uptempo]], [[disco]] [[Groove (music)|groove]], soul infused track. It has been compared to the discographies of [[Michael Jackson]] and [[Stevie Wonder]].<ref name="bbc review"/><ref name="nme review"/> }} "Rock Your Body" has a running duration of four minutes and twenty-seven seconds. The [[Tempo|uptempo]] [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]],<ref name="complex">{{cite news|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2013/03/the-25-best-justin-timberlake-songs/justin-timberlake-rock-your-body|title=The 25 Best Justin Timberlake Songs|date=March 15, 2013|first=Tannis|last=Spencer|work=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]|publisher=Complex Media|accessdate=May 19, 2013}}</ref><ref name="complex1">{{cite news|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2013/03/the-50-best-neptunes-beats/justin-timberlake-rock-your-body|title=The 50 Best Neptunes Beats|date=March 5, 2013|first=Craig|last=Jenkins|work=Complex|publisher=Complex Media|accessdate=June 24, 2013}}</ref> [[disco]] [[Groove (music)|groove]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newsroom.mtv.com/2010/07/21/justin-timberlake-justified-popology/|title=Justin Timberlake Justifies The Existence Of 'Popology'|date=July 21, 2010|first=Kyle|last=Anderson|publisher=MTV News. Viacom|accessdate=May 19, 2013}}</ref> [[Soul music|soul]]<ref name="bbc review">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/vdmq|title=Justin Timberlake Justified Review|date=November 20, 2002 |first=Denise|last=Boyd|publisher=[[BBC Music]]. [[BBC]]|accessdate=March 3, 2013}}</ref> infused song contains influences from both Michael Jackson and [[Stevie Wonder]].<ref name="bbc review"/><ref name="nme review">{{cite news|url=http://www.nme.com/reviews/name/6813 |title=Album Reviews – Justin Timberlake: Justified |date=November 1, 2002|first=Alex |last=Needham |work=[[NME]]|publisher=[[IPC Media]]|accessdate=March 3, 2013}}</ref> The song incorporates tinny, "keyboard-set-to-emulate-clavichord" [[synthesizers]] of [[The Neptunes]]' late 90s productions,<ref name="complex1"/> overlaid with "keys and a propulsive drum vamp".<ref name="complex1"/> Timberlake makes use of his [[falsetto]] range,<ref name="complex"/> and Vanessa Marquez sings the female section.<ref name="mtv5">{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1457770/janet-gets-sexy-on-justin-cd.jhtml|title=Timberlake, Janet Jackson Make Sexy Pair On ''Justified''|last=Wiederhorn|first=Jon|date=September 25, 2002|publisher=MTV News. Viacom|accessdate=February 28, 2013}}</ref> Alex Needham of ''[[NME]]'' noted the track to contain characteristics from material within Jackson's debut solo album ''[[Off the Wall (album)|Off the Wall]]'' (1979).<ref name="nme review"/>
According to the sheet music published at Musicnotes.com by [[Sony/ATV Music Publishing]], "Rock Your Body" is written in the key of [[E minor]] and has a [[tempo]] of 104 beats per minute.<ref name="music notes">{{cite web|url=http://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtdFPE.asp?ppn=MN0044603|title=Justin Timberlake – Rock Your Body|publisher=Musicnotes.com. [[Sony/ATV Music Publishing]] |accessdate=April 15, 2013}}</ref> It follows the [[chord progression]] of F/G-G/A-Em, with Justin Timberlake's vocal range spanning from the low note of B<sub>3</sub> to the high note of D<sub>6</sub>.<ref name="music notes"/> Andy Kellman of [[AllMusic]] noted "Rock Your Body" as a stand-out from ''Justified'',<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r610485|pure_url=yes}} |title=Review: ''Justified''|first=Stephen Thomas |last=Erlewine |publisher=Allmusic. Rovi Corporation|accessdate=February 28, 2013}}</ref> as did Jane Stevenson of [[Jam!]], who interpreted its Jackson influence.<ref name="jam">{{cite web|url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/T/Timberlake_Justin/AlbumReviews/2002/11/14/772032.html|title=Music – Artists – Album Review: Justified|publisher=[[Jam!]]. [[Canoe.ca]]|last=Stevenson|first=Jane|accessdate=May 17, 2012|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HlhD4yr4?url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/T/Timberlake_Justin/AlbumReviews/2002/11/14/772032.html|archivedate=June 30, 2013}}</ref> Giving ''Justified'' a negative review, Caroline Sullivan of ''[[The Guardian]]'' noted "Rock Your Body" as "predictable".<ref name="guardian review">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2002/nov/01/popandrock.artsfeatures6|title=CD: Justin Timberlake: Justified|location=London|date=November 7, 2002|first=Caroline|last=Sullivan|work=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]|accessdate=March 3, 2013}}</ref> ''[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]''{{'s}} Tannis Spenser listed the song as the fifth best Justin Timberlake song, praising its "near perfect sing along chorus" and Timberlake's vocals.<ref name="complex"/>
''[[Pitchfork Media]]'' listed the song at 23 on their list of the best singles of 2003, with editor Dominique Leone writing "Rock Your Body" is "as fine an approximation of ''[[Off the Wall (album)|Off the Wall]]''-era [[Michael Jackson|MJ]] as I've ever heard. The pleading falsetto is right on time, immediately preceded by tough talk about grabbing your girl (and a "couple more")-- the drama!"<ref>{{cite web | url=http://pitchfork.com/features/lists-and-guides/5924-top-50-singles-of-2003/?page=3 | title=Top 50 Singles of 2003 | work=Pitchfork Media | date=December 29, 2003 | accessdate=April 26, 2016}}</ref>
==Chart performance== On the week of March 22, 2003, "Rock Your Body" debuted on the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] at number 61, earning the Hot Shot Debut honor.<ref name="debut">{{cite journal|year=2003|title=Singles Minded|journal=Billboard |page=88|issue=12|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc|doi= |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=fw8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA77&dq=Billboard+march+22+2003&hl=en&sa=X&ei=To5qUdP0NpKN0wXxmoHgCw&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=snippet&q=%22rock%20your%20body%22&f=false|accessdate=April 14, 2013|issn=0006-2510|volume=115}}</ref> The following week, the song entered the top 40 at number 37, and in its third week, reached number 28.<ref>{{cite journal|year=2003|title=Singles Minded|journal=Billboard |page=65|issue=13|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc|doi= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qw8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA69&dq=Billboard+march+28+2003&hl=en&sa=X&ei=t5BqUe_mLMfX0QWKzYFw&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22rock%20your%20body%22&f=false|accessdate=April 14, 2013|issn=0006-2510|volume=115}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|year=2003|title=Singles Minded|journal=Billboard |page=64|issue=14|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc|doi= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VQ8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA59&dq=Billboard+April+5+2003&hl=en&sa=X&ei=cJJqUbSfKabC0QWi14GgDQ&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22rock%20your%20body%22&f=false|accessdate=April 14, 2013|issn=0006-2510|volume=115}}</ref> In its fourth week, the song charted at number 20 on the Hot 100, and in its fifth week, rose further to number 13.<ref>{{cite journal|year=2003|title=Singles Minded|journal=Billboard |page=66|issue=15|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc|doi= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fA0EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA41&dq=Billboard+April+12+2003&hl=en&sa=X&ei=0ZNqUdXIFoeO0AWQy4CYBQ&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22rock%20your%20body%22&f=false|accessdate=April 14, 2013|issn=0006-2510|volume=115}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|year=2003|title=Singles Minded|journal=Billboard |page=57|issue=16|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc|doi= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gg0EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA37&dq=Billboard+April+19+2003&hl=en&sa=X&ei=1pRqUbmmO4PS0QX9xIDoDg&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22rock%20your%20body%22&f=false|accessdate=April 14, 2013|issn=0006-2510|volume=115}}</ref> Within its sixth week, it moved up two positions to number 11, and reached number 10 the following week.<ref>{{cite journal|year=2003|title=Singles Minded|journal=Billboard |page=64|issue=17|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc|doi= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jQ0EAAAAMBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Billboard+April+26+2003&hl=en&sa=X&ei=rJVqUZyKE6OU0AXX6IG4DA&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22rock%20your%20body%22&f=false|accessdate=April 14, 2013|issn=0006-2510|volume=115}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|year=2003|title=Singles Minded|journal=Billboard |page=73|issue=18|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc|doi= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mA0EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA1&dq=Billboard+May+3+2003&hl=en&sa=X&ei=q5ZqUfSIJOnA0QXUzIBw&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22rock%20your%20body%22&f=false|accessdate=April 14, 2013|issn=0006-2510|volume=115}}</ref> "Rock Your Body" eventually reached its peak at number five, where it remained for one week.<ref name="USHot100"/> The song remained on the Hot 100 for 22 weeks before dropping out.<ref name="USHot100"/> The song topped the US [[Mainstream Top 40]] chart, where it remained for one week.<ref name="USpop"/> It was less successful on the US [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs]] chart, where it peaked at number 45.<ref name="USr&b"/> On February 5, 2005, the song was certified gold by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA), for shipments of 500,000 copies.<ref name="us cert"/> As of 2018, the song has sold 2 million copies in the country.<ref name="us sales">{{cite web |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/8097976/justin-timberlake-nsync-career-album-song-sales-ask-billboard|title=Ask Billboard: Justin Timberlake & *NSYNC's Career Album & Song Sales |work=Billboard |publisher=Billboard-Hollywood Media Group |date=February 4, 2018 |accessdate=February 4, 2018 |last=Trust |first=Gary}}</ref>
Internationally, the song was met with a similar response. "Rock Your Body" debuted on the [[ARIA Charts|Australian Singles Chart]] at number one.<ref name="Australia chart"/> It dropped to number three the following week, where it remained in the top ten for six weeks; it stayed on the chart for eleven weeks before dropping out.<ref name="Australia chart"/> The song was certified platinum by the [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA), denoting shipments of 70,000 copies.<ref name="aus cert"/> On the [[UK Singles Chart]], "Rock Your Body" became Timberlake's third consecutive number two hit, following "[[Like I Love You]]" and "[[Cry Me a River (Justin Timberlake song)|Cry Me a River]]".<ref name="UK chart"/> On the [[Recording Industry Association of New Zealand|New Zealand Singles Chart]], "Rock Your Body" achieved its peak on the week of June 22, 2003, its second week on the chart at number four.<ref name="New Zealand chart"/> The song remained on the chart for 20 weeks, and was certified Gold by the [[Recorded Music NZ|Recording Industry Association of New Zealand]] (RIANZ), for shipments of 7,500 copies.<ref name="New Zealand chart"/><ref name="nz cert"/>
It charted within the top five on the [[Tracklisten|Danish Singles Chart]] and [[Irish Singles Chart]], peaking at number three and four, respectively.<ref name="Denmark chart"/><ref name="Ireland chart"/> It peaked at number six on [[Ultratop 50|Belgian Singles Chart]] (Flanders),<ref name="Flanders chart"/> [[The Official Finnish Charts|Finnish Singles Chart]] and [[Single Top 100|Dutch Singles Chart]].<ref name="Finland chart"/><ref name="Dutch chart"/> "Rock Your Body" was less successful in other territories. It charted within the top 20 on the [[Ultratop 50|Belgian Singles Chart]] (Wallonia),<ref name="Wallonia chart"/> [[Syndicat National de l'Édition Phonographique|French Singles Chart]],<ref name="France chart"/> [[Sverigetopplistan|Swedish Singles Charts]] and [[VG-lista|Norwegian Singles Chart]].<ref name="Sweden chart"/><ref name="Norway chart"/> It charted outside the top 20 on the [[Media Control Charts|German Singles Chart]],<ref name="Germany chart"/> [[Swiss Hitparade|Swiss Singles Chart]] and [[Ö3 Austria Top 40|Austrian Singles Chart]]; the latter chart is the song's lowest charting territory, where it peaked at number 56.<ref name="Switzerland"/><ref name="Austria chart"/>
==Music video== [[File:Rock Your Body scene.PNG|thumb|left|Timberlake dancing inside a cube surrounded by an array of colored lights.]] The music video was directed by [[Francis Lawrence]] and filmed in February 2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1459732/justin-timberlake-on-tourmate-christina-shes-bad/|title=Justin Timberlake On Tourmate Christina: 'She's Bad'|last=Wiederhorn|first=Jon|website=[[MTV News]]|date=January 28, 2003|access-date=February 12, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Railton|first=Diane|date=July 7, 2011|title=Music Video and the Politics of Representation|page=165}}</ref> It opens within a black cube with an array of different colored lights with several people dancing. The video inter-cuts to Justin Timberlake singing to the song. Timberlake then floats to the floor from an opening in the cubic's ceiling, performing choreography with his supporting dancers and singing to the track's first verse. Throughout the video, it inter-cuts to Timberlake dancing by himself, with the sections sometimes featuring the camera panning around Timberlake's face. Entering the second verse, Timberlake is in the cube on his own, manipulating the motion of the cube with his hands, with his legs following the moving platform. Timberlake then returns performing choreography again with his dancers.
Following the second chorus, Timberlake is dancing with [[Staci Flood]], who lip syncs Vanessa Marquez's section. A break-down of the song, where Timberlake is [[beatboxing]], shows him dancing by himself. The first beatboxing section of the song is only available in the music video version; the audio version doesn't include the first beatboxing part. The breakdown then ends, with the video continuing with Timberlake and his back-up dancers. The closing beat boxing section of the track features the camera panning around several duplicates of Timberlake beatboxing and talking in sync to the song's lyrics. The video ends with the final Timberlake duplicate pointing and running towards the opposite direction.
==Live performances== Justin Timberlake performed "Rock Your Body" during his [[Justified World Tour]] and the [[Christina Aguilera]] conjoint tour [[Justified & Stripped Tour]], both in support of his debut album ''Justified''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nme.com/news/justin-timberlake/15661|title=JT returns to the UK|date=December 2, 2003|work=NME|publisher=IPC Media|accessdate=May 19, 2013}}</ref> Timberlake performed the song live on the sketch comedy show ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' in October 2003, where he served as host and musical guest.<ref>{{cite episode |title=Justin Timberlake |episodelink= |series=Saturday Night Live |serieslink= |credits= |network=[[NBC]] |station= |airdate=2003-10-11 |season=[[Saturday Night Live (season 29)|29]] |seriesno= |number=547 |minutes=90-92 }}</ref> On February 1, 2004, Timberlake performed the song with [[pop music|pop]] singer [[Janet Jackson]] during her performance at the [[Super Bowl XXXVIII halftime show]].<ref name="apologeticjackson">{{cite news|title=Apologetic Jackson says 'costume reveal' went awry|publisher= [[CNN|CNN.com]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=February 3, 2004|url=http://www.cnn.com/2004/US/02/02/superbowl.jackson/|accessdate=July 27, 2007}}</ref> At the moment he sang the lyric "I'll have you naked by the end of this song," the singer ripped off part of Jackson's outfit, momentarily exposing her right [[breast]] on live television.<ref name="apologeticjackson"/> Timberlake distanced himself from the controversy while Jackson faced much criticism and backlash. He later commented that "America's harsher on women...[and] unfairly harsh on ethnic people."<ref>{{cite web|last=Moss|first= Corey|author2=Norris, John |title=Justin Timberlake's Future Shock|url=http://www.mtv.com/bands/t/timberlake_justin/news_feature_081506/|publisher=MTV News. Viacom|date=August 15, 2006|accessdate=August 14, 2007}}</ref> Timberlake performed the song at the [[Hollywood Palladium]], following his performance at the [[2013 Grammy Awards|55th Annual Grammy Awards]] on February 10, 2013.<ref>{{cite news|first=Mesfin|last=Fekadu|title=Justin Timberlake's Post-Grammys Show: Singer Performs At Hollywood Palladium After Awards|publisher=AOL|work=The Huffington Post|date= February 11, 2013|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/02/11/justin-timberlake-post-grammys-show-palladium_n_2663549.html|accessdate=May 19, 2013}}</ref> He performed "Rock Your Body" in a medley with other of his songs at the [[2013 MTV Video Music Awards]]. In 2016, the singer performed the song along with "[[Can't Stop the Feeling!]]" during the interval act of the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016]] grand finale.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/news/watch-justin-timberlake-perform-at-eurovision-2016-rock-your-body-cant-stop-the-feeling-a7029996.html | title=Watch Justin Timberlake perform at Eurovision 2016 | work=Independent | date=May 14, 2016 | accessdate=May 14, 2016}}</ref>
"Rock Your Body" was featured on [[The Justified World Tour]] (2003/04), [[Justified and Stripped Tour]] (2003), [[FutureSex/LoveShow]] (2007), [[Legends of the Summer]] (2013) and [[The 20/20 Experience World Tour]] (2013/14). He again performed the song during the [[Super Bowl LII halftime show]] in 2018, this time abruptly stopping the "have you naked..." line and, after a brief pause, segueing into another song.
==Track listing== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} *;European CD single #"Rock Your Body" (Album Version) — 4:28 #"Rock Your Body" ([[Sander Kleinenberg]]'s Just in the Radio Edit) — 3:33
*;French CD single #"Rock Your Body" (Album Version) — 4:28 #"Rock Your Body" ([[Paul Oakenfold]] Radio Edit) — 3:50 #"Rock Your Body" (Video)
*;CD maxi single #"Rock Your Body" (Album Version) — 4:28 #"Rock Your Body" (Sander Kleinenberg's Just in the Radio Edit) — 3:33 #"Rock Your Body" (Paul Oakenfold Mix) — 5:41 #"Rock Your Body" (Instrumental with Beatbox) — 4:28 {{col-2}} *;Cassette single #"Rock Your Body" (Album Version) — 4:28 #"Rock Your Body" (Sander Kleinenberg's Just in the Radio Edit) — 3:33 #"Worthy Of" — 4:09
*;12" vinyl #"Rock Your Body" (Album Version) — 4:28 #"Rock Your Body" (Paul Oakenfold Mix) — 5:41 #"Rock Your Body" (Sander Kleinenberg's Just in the Club Mix) — 9:32 {{col-end}}
==Personnel== Credits adapted from [[AllMusic]].<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r641694/credits|pure_url=yes}} |title=Credits: Rock Your Body|publisher=Allmusic. Rovi Corporation|accessdate=April 13, 2013}}</ref>
*David Betancourt – assistant engineer *Andrew Coleman – engineer *Eddie DeLena – vocal engineer *[[Serban Ghenea]] – mixing *Ian Green – engineer, programming *Chaz Harpe – mastering *[[Chad Hugo]] – instrumentation, producer *Eelke Kalberg – producer *[[Sander Kleinenberg]] – producer, remixing *S. Molijn – producer *[[Paul Oakenfold]] – remixing *Herb Powers – mastering *[[Tim Roberts]] – assistant engineer *[[Justin Timberlake]] – primary artist, vocal arrangement, vocals *[[Pharrell Williams]] – instrumentation, producer, vocal arrangement, vocals
==Charts== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}}
===Weekly charts=== {|class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" ! scope="col"|Chart (2003) ! scope="col"|Peak<br>position |- ! scope="row" {{singlechart|Australia|1|artist=Justin Timberlake|song=Rock Your Body|accessdate=April 11, 2011|refname=Australia chart}} |- ! scope="row" {{singlechart|Austria|56|artist=Justin Timberlake|song=Rock Your Body|accessdate=April 11, 2011|refname=Austria chart}} |- ! scope="row" {{singlechart|Flanders|6|artist=Justin Timberlake|song=Rock Your Body|accessdate=April 11, 2011}} |- ! scope="row" {{singlechart|Flanders Dance|6|artist=Justin Timberlake|song=Rock Your Body|accessdate=April 11, 2011|refname=Flanders chart}} |- ! scope="row" {{singlechart|Wallonia|14|artist=Justin Timberlake|song=Rock Your Body|accessdate=April 11, 2011|refname=Wallonia chart}} |- ! scope="row" {{singlechart|Wallonia Dance|6|artist=Justin Timberlake|song=Rock Your Body|accessdate=April 11, 2011}} |- ! scope="row" {{singlechart|Denmark|3|artist=Justin Timberlake|song=Rock Your Body|accessdate=April 11, 2011|refname=Denmark chart}} |- ! ==Cover versions and appearances in other media== *[[Shawn Lee (musician)|Shawn Lee]]'s Ping Pong Orchestra performed an instrumental cover of the song on their album, ''Hits the Hits!''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.whosampled.com/cover/view/30024/Shawn%20Lee's%20Ping%20Pong%20Orchestra-Rock%20Your%20Body_Justin%20Timberlake%20feat.%20Vanessa%20Marquez-Rock%20Your%20Body/|title=Shawn Lee's Ping Pong Orchestra's cover|publisher=[[WhoSampled]]. Nadav Poraz|accessdate=April 4, 2013}}</ref> *The song was regularly covered live by the [[experimental rock]] band [[Tub Ring]], and was recorded as a [[B-side]] to their 2007 album, ''[[The Great Filter]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.last.fm/music/Tub+Ring/_/Rock+Your+Body|title=Tub Ring – Rock Your Body|publisher=[[Last.fm]]. [[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=April 4, 2013}}</ref> *The song was briefly featured in the ninth season of ''[[South Park]]'' episode "[[Marjorine]]".<ref>{{cite book|last=Gournelos|first=Ted|authorlink= |title=Popular Culture and the Future of Politics: Cultural Studies and the Tao of South Park|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PCI23BOylt4C&pg=PA56&lpg=PA56&dq=Marjorine+justin+timberlake&source=bl&ots=9EGd9xGdTC&sig=LOjZMAPWqdePYCEvF12Te4FtV4Q&hl=en&sa=X&ei=srNcUeqwLce70QXgvIDIAQ&ved=0CDoQ6AEwATgK#v=onepage&q=Marjorine%20justin%20timberlake&f=false|accessdate=April 4, 2013|year=2009|publisher=[[Rowman & Littlefield]]|location= |isbn=0739137212|page=56}}</ref> *The song appears in the 2007 video game ''[[Dance Dance Revolution SuperNova 2 (2007 video game)|Dance Dance Revolution SuperNova 2]]''.
